articles.headline: Awaiting a Greek Payout
articles.snippet: A growing number of investors are loading up on Greek government securities that mature in March, betting on a rescue that would provide them with a huge profit.
articles.abstract: A growing number of investors are loading up on Greek government securities that mature in March, betting on a rescue that would provide them with a huge profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Could Greece’s next rescue payout go straight into the pockets of London hedge funds?

articles.headline: TV Decency Is a Puzzler for Justices
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court justices heard arguments on whether the government still has good reason to regulate cursing and nudity on broadcast television.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court justices heard arguments on whether the government still has good reason to regulate cursing and nudity on broadcast television.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a rollicking Supreme Court argument that was equal parts cultural criticism and First Amendment doctrine, the justices on Tuesday considered whether the government still had good reason to regulate cursing and nudity on broadcast television.

articles.headline: Romney Wins G.O.P. Primary in New Hampshire
articles.snippet: The outcome was a measure of strength for Mitt Romney and a test for challengers seeking a strong performance to propel them into the South Carolina primary.
articles.abstract: The outcome was a measure of strength for Mitt Romney and a test for challengers seeking a strong performance to propel them into the South Carolina primary.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Mitt Romney swept to victory in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, turning back a ferocious assault from rivals who sought to disqualify him in the eyes of conservatives, in a contest that failed to anoint a strong opponent to slow his march to the Republican nomination.

articles.headline: G.M. Looks to Luxury Cars for Higher Profit
articles.snippet: The crisis in Europe is leading General Motors to emphasize new luxury models meant to improve sales in America.
articles.abstract: The crisis in Europe is leading General Motors to emphasize new luxury models meant to improve sales in America.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After a humbling bankruptcy and $50 billion government bailout in 2009, General Motors has rebounded with steady profits and a fresh lineup of competitive vehicles.

articles.headline: Dividends Rise in Sign of Recovery
articles.snippet: If analysts’ forecasts come true, higher dividend payouts will continue in 2012, as companies release more cash and try to win over investors.
articles.abstract: If analysts’ forecasts come true, higher dividend payouts will continue in 2012, as companies release more cash and try to win over investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every year since 1976, McDonald’s has increased its annual payout to shareholders. This year it will keep the streak alive, raising its annual dividend to $2.80. In doing so, it will join a broad range of companies that weathered a challenging economy and are now delivering their best payments to shareholders since the financial crisis.

articles.headline: In South Carolina, Challenges Await on Ideology and Faith
articles.snippet: If Mitt Romney succeeds in South Carolina, a place famous for surfacing the dark undercurrents of American politics, it will be a triumph of political rebranding.
articles.abstract: If Mitt Romney succeeds in South Carolina, a place famous for surfacing the dark undercurrents of American politics, it will be a triumph of political rebranding.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Mitt Romney has now defied a generation of political gravity, doing what no non-incumbent Republican has done since the Iowa caucuses became a key part of the campaign in the 1970s, winning the one-two states of Iowa and New Hampshire in his quest for the party’s presidential nomination.

articles.headline: Big Banks Face Inquiry Over Home Insurance
articles.snippet: New York State is investigating whether several banks fraudulently steered homeowners into overpriced policies.
articles.abstract: New York State is investigating whether several banks fraudulently steered homeowners into overpriced policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: A New York State financial services agency is investigating several large banks to see whether they fraudulently steered homeowners into overpriced insurance policies.

articles.headline: With Enough Bandwidth, Many Join the Band
articles.snippet: Videochat programs like Skype are transforming the way many people learn to play musical instruments.
articles.abstract: Videochat programs like Skype are transforming the way many people learn to play musical instruments.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Dr. John McClure, a pathologist in Edina, Minn., was pondering his wish list several years ago, he added something a little out of the ordinary: learn to play the bagpipes. But his goal seemed like a long shot after a friend who had been teaching him moved away.

articles.headline: Back From War, Fear and Danger Fill Driver’s Seat
articles.snippet: Erratic driving by returning troops is being identified as a symptom of traumatic brain injury or post-traumatic stress disorder — and coming under greater scrutiny.
articles.abstract: Erratic driving by returning troops is being identified as a symptom of traumatic brain injury or post-traumatic stress disorder — and coming under greater scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Before going to war, Susan Max loved tooling around Northern California in her maroon Mustang. A combat tour in Iraq changed all that.

articles.headline: Economic Woes Loom Larger as G.O.P. Heads South
articles.snippet: As it enters South Carolina, the Republican presidential race is coming for the first time to a state that is struggling mightily through the downturn.
articles.abstract: As it enters South Carolina, the Republican presidential race is coming for the first time to a state that is struggling mightily through the downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH, S.C. — The grim just gets grimmer here at the Edisto Grocery, where all day long people with not enough work come to eat $2.25 fried bologna sandwiches, pick up some horse feed and complain about the price of diesel.
